fields.name: JACKIE MARIE PORTMAN-BROWN
fields.bio: Jackie Marie Portman-Brown was elected to the bench in 2008 and was retained in 2014. Before becoming a judge, Portman-Brown was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney for seven years and the general counsel of the Independent Police Review Authority, the now-defunct agency that investigated Chicago police misconduct. She served as a judge overseeing bond hearings and traffic matters until 2012, when she was assigned to oversee deferred prosecution programs and a specialty court called the HOPE court. Portman-Brown was hearing felony narcotics matters before she was placed on administrative duty.
fields.notable:
In February, Judge Portman-Brown was [placed on administrative duty](https://chicago.suntimes.com/2020/2/27/21156105/cook-county-judge-jackie-portman-brown-surveillance-video-jail-locking-up-child) after she was captured on video locking her 6-year old grandniece alone in a holding cell for approximately ten minutes. She has self-identified in media interviews as a [“lock ‘em up” judge](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W8BT3oIQKO4) and has been criticized for her temperament on the bench. In 2018, the [HOPE court program she ran was shut down](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2018/hope-cook-county-court-program-halted-after-years-of-problems/) after two separate outside reviews called into question her “bullying” behavior in the courtroom and the program’s efficacy.

In a statement, a spokesperson for Portman-Brown said, “Unfortunately, the media’s perception of the incident with the grandniece was not a true representation of the matter in question.”
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA said many attorneys "raised concerns about her judgment, and there were also concerns about her temperament, with some describing her as abusive to the courtroom staff and her unorthodox behavior on the bench, including singing and ringing a cowbell."

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN NIXON
THOMAS M. CUSHING
fields.bio: Thomas Cushing was appointed to fill a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in June 2019 and currently hears cases in the domestic violence court. Cushing was previously an attorney in private practice, working on civil and commercial litigation, personal injury, and appellate cases. Cushing has also worked in environmental law. Cushing ran unsuccessfully for judge in 2014 and 2016.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and ISBA noted Cushing’s “extensive” litigation experience and his demeanor. The CCL praised him for his litigation skills and wrote that he “has been involved with numerous community activities, including teaching and environmental advocacy.”

fields.name: general for COOK CIRCUIT- FORD VACANCY
PATRICK J. SHERLOCK
fields.bio: Patrick J. Sherlock was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2007 and elected in 2008. Since 2013, he has heard commercial cases in the law division. Before becoming a judge, Sherlock was an attorney in private practice, primarily handling commercial litigation.
fields.notable:
In 2019, Sherlock and another attorney requested more than $2 million in fees for a lawsuit they had worked on for two years in the early 2000s. The case, which involved a group of investors, lasted more than 17 years, and in December 2018, Cook County Circuit Judge Neil H. Cohen issued a ruling ordering the defendants to pay more than $116 million. After Sherlock’s former law partner filed a motion for their fees, the defendants asked to have the judge remove himself from the case and have it assigned to a judge outside of Cook County instead, [arguing that it was unfair](https://cookcountyrecord.com/stories/511802687-too-close-cook-county-judge-asks-millions-in-fees-for-prior-legal-work-defendants-judge-s-colleagues-can-t-rule) for one of Sherlock’s colleagues to decide whether to award him legal fees. Sherlock later withdrew his request that Judge Cohen determine his fee.

Sherlock is one of four judges running for retention this year with more than a dozen cases reversed by the Appellate Court in the past six years. In an emailed statement, Sherlock said the reversals represent just 0.5% of the 2,422 cases he has "disposed of by dismissal" since January 2014.

fields.name: general for COOK CIRCUIT- PATTI VACANCY
Judge tried to kiss Chicago cop, asked court reporter 'how much' for sex, board charges
FRANK R. DiFRANCO
fields.bio: After beginning his career as an assistant state’s attorney, Frank DiFranco has worked in private practice since 1994. He represents clients in civil and criminal cases, including wrongful death and personal injury cases.
fields.notable:
DiFranco is accused in a pending civil lawsuit of helping disgraced former detective Reynaldo Guevara frame a man named Jose Maysonet for a double murder in July 1990. According to the suit, DiFranco, who had just begun working in felony review for the state’s attorney’s office, took a coerced confession from Maysonet and his girlfriend after a marathon interrogation session in which Guevara repeatedly beat him. The suit also alleges that DiFranco lied on the stand during Maysonet’s trial when he said that he took the confession in English, even though Maysonet did not speak fluent English at the time, according to his attorney. In a deposition taken last year, DiFranco maintained that he took Maysonet’s statement in English. Maysonet’s conviction was vacated in 2016 and in 2017 prosecutors decided not to re-try the case.

In an email to *Injustice Watch*, DiFranco denied Maysonet’s allegations and said that he still believes that Maysonet is guilty. “I have never and would never fabricate a statement of a defendant or anyone else for that matter,” he wrote. 

DiFranco was also an attorney and close friend of Rev. John P. Smyth, the former head of Maryville Academy, a Catholic school for troubled kids in Des Plaines. DiFranco adamantly defended Smyth against accusations that he sexually abused several boys during his time as head of the school. “It never happened. It’s a lie. The stuff that was alleged is nonsense,” he [told the Sun-Times last year](https://chicago.suntimes.com/2019/1/21/18419959/lawyer-for-ex-maryville-priest-calls-sex-abuse-allegations-ridiculous). Smyth died in April 2019, a few months after the Archdiocese of Chicago removed him from ministry. DiFranco also sits on the board of the John P. Smyth Standing Tall Charitable Foundation, a charity Smyth started.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted DiFranco’s “extensive experience in a wide range of civil and criminal matters.” The ISBA said there were some “mixed comments” on his temperament, with a few attorneys saying he could be “argumentative at times.” The CCL said he “enjoys a reputation of being a zealous and knowledgeable advocate.”

fields.name: Big Pensions For Small Sewage Board
DANIEL EDWARD MALONEY
fields.bio: Judge Daniel E. Maloney presides over municipal cases at the Markham Courthouse. Maloney, appointed in 2019 to a 3rd subcircuit Cook County Circuit Court vacancy, spent the first 16 years of his career working as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney, where he prosecuted drug cases before joining the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration as division counsel in 2017.
fields.notable: In 2009, as a Cook County prosecutor, Maloney worked with DEA agents and the State’s Attorney’s office on an investigation into two drug rings importing from Mexico that resulted in 10 arrests and the seizure of more than $8.7 million worth of heroin and cocaine. The drug bust was one of the largest in county history.
fields.ratingNotes: CBA noted Maloney’s legal knowledge and demeanor. ISBA said opposing attorneys described him as “a tough litigator, but fair and ethical.” CCL said, “He is reported to be an excellent mentor to less experienced lawyers.”

fields.name: Bill would legalize recording cops in public
general for 1ST APPELLATE - NEVILLE, JR. VACANCY
Illinois appellate court rejects ordinance banning detention of 10-12 year olds
Meet Cook County’s tough love judge
CYNTHIA Y. COBBS
fields.bio:
Cynthia Cobbs has been serving as an Illinois Appellate Court judge since the Illinois Supreme Court assigned her in 2015. Earlier this year, Cobbs ran an unsuccessful campaign for the Supreme Court. She would have been the first Black woman to become an Illinois Supreme Court justice.

Cobbs was a social worker in Maryland before moving to Illinois, attending law school, and being admitted to the Illinois bar in 1988. Cobbs went to work for eight years as a law clerk for Illinois Supreme Court Justice Charles Freeman, the first Black person and person of color to serve on the state’s highest court. Cobbs spent more than a decade in the Administrative Office of the Illinois Courts, including nine years as its director, before she was appointed as a Circuit Court judge in 2011. She won an election to keep her Circuit Court seat in 2014 before she was assigned to the Appellate Court the following year.
fields.notable: Cobbs’s 2011 appointment to the Cook County Circuit Court generated controversy because she lived in Will County at the time, which some legal experts said violated residency requirements. Cobbs was also the first of two of Freeman’s former law clerks to be appointed to a Circuit Court seat within a two-year period. In 2013, the Chicago Tribune [published a critique](https://www.chicagotribune.com/opinion/ct-xpm-2013-03-11-ct-edit-judges-20130311-story.html) of the Supreme Court’s appointments, maintaining that “judges should be chosen based on merit, not political ties.”

fields.name: Cook County judge put on "administrative duty," after surveillance video shows her locking up child
SUSANNE MICHELE GROEBNER
fields.currentJob: Assistant state’s attorney in McHenry County
fields.bio: Susanne Groebner currently works as an assistant state’s attorney in McHenry County after spending 17 years as a prosecutor in Cook County, where she was last assigned to a felony courtroom in Rolling Meadows. Groebner also has experience in civil litigation, particularly in the area of family law.
fields.notable: Groebner previously ran for judge as a Republican. She lost the 2018 Republican primary for a 13th subcircuit seat to Gary Seyring.
fields.ratingNotes: The bar associations noted Groebner’s experience trying complex cases. The CBA said she is “well respected by judges and lawyers for her knowledge of the law, outstanding trial skills, fine demeanor and temperament.” The CCL praised her as “an honest and fair prosecutor.” ISBA said she is “well prepared, honest, and impartial.”

fields.name: Drug busts only as good as cop’s word
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN MARTINEZ
TYRIA B. WALTON
fields.bio: Tyria Walton was appointed to the bench in May 2019, and currently oversees traffic cases at the Daley Center. Previously, she served for more than two decades as an assistant public defender, where she worked in the felony trial division defending first-degree murder cases.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted that Walton “served on the Public Defender’s Murder Task Force” and that she “serves as a mentor for children and young adults in the Englewood community.” The CCL praised her legal ability and “substantial litigation experience in complex matters.” The ISBA highlighted her community involvement and her “high integrity.”

fields.name: PATRICIA M. FALLON
fields.bio: Patricia M. Fallon was appointed to fill the Hanlon vacancy in May 2019. She currently oversees first municipal district traffic cases in the Daley Center. Before her appointment to the bench, Fallon was the chief of human resources in the Cook County Recorder of Deeds office. Before that, Fallon worked in the labor and employment litigation unit of the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office for more than 12 years, including almost two years as a supervisor. In that role, she defended the county against employment discrimination lawsuits.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA cited Fallon’s knowledge, trial experience and “excellent temperament and demeanor.” The CCL said she had “good legal ability” and is “praised for her supervisory skills.” The ISBA noted her experience in jury trials, appeals, and employment matters.

fields.name: general for COOK - 8TH SUBCIRCUIT - GUBIN VACANCY
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN MITCHELL
general for COOK - 10TH SUBCIRCUIT - O'BRIEN VACANCY
A judge-to-be beat our flawed selection system
WILLIAM B. RAINES
fields.bio: William B. Raines was elected to the Circuit Court in 2014 and is assigned to the criminal division. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private practice and for insurance companies on fraud investigations. He is a former Oakland, Calif., police officer and Cook County sheriff’s deputy and worked for one year in the narcotics division of the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN WARD KIRBY
In two cases, Illinois appeals judges split on protections in criminal cases
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN BUFORD
Notable reversals
fields.description: A high number of reversals can cause a judge to lose the respect of their peers, appellate judges and litigants, who have concern about the permanence of the judge’s decision in their case. Many reversals or a pattern of reversals based on the same legal issues could be a sign that a judge is repeatedly misapplying the law.

fields.name: PATRICIA O'BRIEN SHEAHAN
fields.bio: Patricia O’Brien Sheahan was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014 and is currently assigned to the law division, where she hears personal injury and other civil cases. Before becoming a judge, she spent three years as an associate at a large firm practicing civil and commercial litigation. From 1999 until she was elected to the bench, she was an attorney for the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (now the Shirley Ryan AbilityLab), defending against medical malpractice and liability claims. She has served on the governing board of the Center for Disability and Elder Law.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN ALLEGRETTI
JAMES PAUL PIECZONKA
fields.bio: James Paul Pieczonka was elected to the Circuit Court in 2014 as a Republican. He supervises the civil arbitration call and presides over other civil matters in the third municipal division in Rolling Meadows. Before becoming a judge, he was an attorney in private practice for 30 years, practicing litigation and transactional law. He also worked as an administrative law judge for the Illinois Department of Revenue and as a hearing officer for the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District.
fields.notable:
Pieczonka ran an unsuccessful campaign for the bench in 2012. In his 2014 race, his supporters challenged his opponent’s candidacy, claiming that Pieczonka’s opponent didn’t actually reside in Cook County. Pieczonka was found not qualified by all but one bar association, the Hispanic Lawyers Association of Illinois, in 2014.

In 2015, he found then-Ald. Rey Colon not guilty of drunk driving in a bench trial. "His eyes appear to be a little bloodshot, not completely bloodshot — I've seen a lot worse," Pieczonka said of Colon’s mugshot, according to the [Chicago Tribune](https://www.chicagotribune.com/politics/ct-colon-not-guilty-dui-met-20150105-story.html).

fields.name: general for COOK - 14TH SUBCIRCUIT- BERTUCCI VACANCY
MARITZA MARTINEZ
fields.bio: Maritza Martinez was elected to the Circuit Court in 2014. Before becoming a judge, she spent about a decade as an associate at various local law firms, practicing criminal defense and civil rights law. Before that, Martinez was an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago, prosecuting municipal ordinance violations and representing the city and its employees in civil litigation. She has also served on the Inquiry Board and Oversight Committee for the Illinois Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission, which evaluates misconduct complaints against attorneys.

fields.name: SHEREE DESIREE HENRY
fields.bio: Sheree Henry was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in July 2019. Prior to her appointment, Henry worked as an assistant public defender for two decades. Before that, she spent four years as an assistant public guardian, representing children in abuse and neglect cases. Henry currently oversees traffic cases at the Daley Center.
fields.notable: Henry served in the Illinois Army National Guard for eight years.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA mentioned her “passionate advocacy on behalf of her clients” during her time as a public defender prior to her appointment as judge. The CCL referenced Henry’s “substantial bench and jury litigation experience.” The ISBA noted her “sensitivity to racial and ethnic diversity issues.” She was the only candidate of four running for the Murphy Gorman vacancy to receive a qualified rating from all three bar associations.

fields.name: 3rd Subcircuit
fields.description: The 3rd subcircuit includes parts of the Southwest Side, including Midway, Marquette Park, Beverly and Mt. Greenwood. It also includes the southwest suburbs of Burbank, Hometown, and Evergreen Park, and the northeast corner of Oak Lawn.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN LAWLER

CCL Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has demonstrated the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in the areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character).

fields.name: Another bad way to pick judges
15th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 15th subcircuit covers the south and southwest suburbs of Flossmoor, Chicago Heights, Matteson, Oak Forest, Tinley Park, Oak Forest and Orland Park.

fields.name: TIESHA L. SMITH
fields.bio: Tiesha L. Smith has worked in the Cook County Public Defender’s Office since 2010. Before that, she practiced in insurance defense litigation and foreclosure mediation and worked as an attorney for Chicago Public Schools. Smith ran unsuccessfully for the Cook County Circuit Court 2nd subcircuit in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: Smith was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.description: The 7th subcircuit extends west along the Eisenhower Expressway from the West Loop to the west suburbs of Berwyn, Forest Park and River Forest (but does not include Oak Park). It includes the West Side neighborhoods of Garfield Park, North Lawndale, Homan Square and Austin, and part of West Humboldt Park.

Chicago cop on Mayor Lightfoot’s security detail cleared of misdemeanor domestic battery charge
ABBEY FISHMAN ROMANEK
fields.bio: Abbey Fishman Romanek was elected to the bench in 2014 and currently hears cases in the domestic relations division. Before becoming a judge, Romanek spent much of her career in private practice working on medical malpractice cases. She also spent several years as a criminal defense lawyer and worked in the Medicaid fraud division in the Illinois Attorney General’s office. Romanek serves on the board of the Illinois Holocaust Museum and Sukkat Shalom Temple in Wilmette.
fields.notable: Romanek has presided over the child custody cases of former Chicago Bears linebacker Brian Urlacher and Chance the Rapper.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN COBBS
10th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 10th subcircuit covers much of the Northwest Side, including North Center, Ravenswood, Albany Park, Jefferson Park, Norwood Park and Edison Park. It also includes parts of Niles and Park Ridge.

fields.name: THOMAS J. CARROLL
fields.bio: Thomas J. Caroll was first appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2011 and later elected in 2014. Before becoming a judge, Caroll was an assistant public defender and also worked in private practice, primarily as a criminal defense attorney. He currently hears misdemeanor criminal cases in the Markham courthouse.
fields.notable: After being appointed to the bench in 2011, Carroll dropped out of the judicial primary in 2012, leaving only Daniel Degnan, the son of an aide to former Mayor Richard M. Daley, to run unopposed for the seat. Degnan was favored by the Democratic Party, despite receiving negative ratings from the bar associations. Two months later, the Supreme Court reappointed Carroll to a new vacancy. "I don't know if that helped or not," Carroll told the Chicago Tribune about his decision to drop out of the race. "The Supreme Court liked me so they reappointed me."

fields.name: general for COOK - 14TH SUBCIRCUIT- LACY VACANCY
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN COGHLAN
PETER A. FELICE
fields.bio: Peter A. Felice was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2002. He currently hears cases in the fifth municipal district in Bridgeview. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private practice, representing many suburban townships and villages, and heard administrative cases. He was also an elected trustee of the South Lyons Sanitary District from 1986 to 2002.
fields.notable:
A [2016 Injustice Watch investigation](https://www.injusticewatch.org/interactives/jail-roulette/) into bond court practices found that Felice often took more time asking questions of defendants and attorneys in his Bridgeview bond court than his counterparts in Central Bond Court. But in one case, on the day of a colleague’s retirement party, Felice sped up the process, interrupting a defense attorney and setting a $270,000 bond in a felony theft case that was later reduced to $50,000.

As a former South Lyons Sanitary District trustee, Felice could be eligible for a significant pension when he retires, even though the job was part-time, [the Better Government Association reported in 2015](https://www.bettergov.org/news/big-pensions-for-small-sewage-board/). Felice and his wife, Susan Felice, who also served on the sanitary district board, fought a 2011 finding by an auditor for the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, which administers the pension plan, to strip them of their pensions for not working the minimum required hours. The BGA reported that Felice could be eligible for $48,600 a year from the sanitary district, on top of his judicial pension, even though he contributed just $3,521 to the pension fund during his 16 years on the board. Felice declined to comment.

fields.name: 9th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 9th subcircuit covers the North Side neighborhoods of Rogers Park and West Ridge and the north suburbs of Evanston, Skokie, Lincolnwood and Wilmette. It is home to the court's Skokie court house.

fields.name: EDWARD A. ARCE
fields.bio: Edward A. Arce was appointed to the Circuit Court in February 2008, before running unopposed to keep his seat. He was retained in 2014. He currently hears cases in the domestic relations division. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private practice as a litigator at the firm Whitcup and Arce. He got his bachelor’s degree at the University of Illinois and his law degree at the Illinois Institute of Technology Chicago-Kent College of Law.

fields.name: Lawsuit alleges judicial candidate helped Detective Guevara frame an innocent man
fields.description: Frank DiFranco, who is running for judge in the 12th subcircuit Republican primary, is accused of knowingly taking a false confession that sent a man to prison for 27 years.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN HYMAN
SHELLEY LYNN SUTKER-DERMER
fields.bio: Shelley Lynn Sutker-Dermer was appointed to the Circuit Court in 1995 and she was elected to the bench the following year. She has been the presiding judge of the second municipal district in Skokie since 2003. Before becoming a judge, Sutker-Dermer spent 12 years as a Cook County assistant state’s attorney.
fields.notable: Sutker-Dermer’s father, Calvin Sutker, was a longtime Democratic committeeman in Niles, Skokie village trustee, and former chairman of the Illinois Democratic Party. He was also close friends with Cook County Chief Judge Timothy Evans.

10 Circuit Court judges picked; Several have Daley connections

general for COOK CIRCUIT- FUNDERBURK VACANCY
A first for Illinois: An openly transgender judicial candidate
SHARON O. JOHNSON
fields.bio: Sharon Johnson was first elected as a Cook County Circuit Court judge in 2010, beating a five-person field in the primary from the 1st subcircuit. Johnson is assigned to the domestic relations division at the Markham Courthouse, which handles divorce, child custody and support matters. Previously, she worked for more than a decade in private practice, focusing on real estate, corporate and family law. Johnson ran unsuccessfully for a seat on the Illinois Appellate Court in 2014.
fields.notable: In her first years on the bench, Johnson received negative ratings from bar associations, which cited issues with her temperament and court management. But by the time she successfully ran for retention in 2016 Johnson’s ratings improved, with praise for both her work ethic, legal ability, and thoroughness of her preparation.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA reported that Johnson is “bright and prepared with good legal knowledge” and said she is “patient with litigants and has a calm demeanor.” The CCL said she is “an excellent jurist” and the CBA praised her experience, work ethic, diligence and demeanor.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN WADAS
JULIE BESS AIMEN
fields.bio: Julie Aimen is a civil rights, criminal defense and family law attorney who began her legal career in 1984 and runs a private practice in downtown Chicago. Aimen was the first woman president of the Illinois Association for Criminal Defense Lawyers, and is also a past member of the Board of Governors of the Chicago Council of Lawyers. Before her legal career, Aimen was a social worker in Cook County, working with war veterans, victims of domestic violence, substance abusers and people with mental illness, according to her campaign website.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA praised Aimen’s “substantial” experience in complex matters, and the CBA highlighted her “knowledge of the law, legal ability, and calm demeanor.” The CCL emphasized her pro bono work and described her as “a zealous advocate for her clients. Her integrity is unquestioned.”

fields.name: general for COOK CIRCUIT- SHEEHAN, K. VACANCY
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN GOLDISH
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN MEYERSON
After diversity concerns, appointed subcircuit judge declines to run
JOHN G. MULROE
fields.bio: John Mulroe was appointed to fill a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court 10th subcircuit in June 2019. Prior to his appointment, Mulroe served as a state senator for nearly a decade. He began his career as an assistant state’s attorney for six years before spending over two decades in private practice. He has also been a hearing officer for the City of Chicago and an arbitrator in the Cook County Mandatory Arbitration Program. Mulroe ran unsuccessfully for the 10th subcircuit in 2008.
fields.notable: As a state senator, Mulroe was chairman of the Senate Public Health Committee and received thousands of dollars in contributions from pharmaceutical companies and industry groups.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA called Mulroe “a dedicated public servant” and praised his legal knowledge, experience and temperament. The ISBA said he is “a well-rounded attorney who treats all with respect.” The CCL also cited his trial skills, integrity and temperament.

fields.name: general for COOK CIRCUIT- ROTI VACANCY
Lawsuit ties judge to 2002 murder conviction involving alleged police coercion
Chicago appeals court yanks $14 million award v. ISMIE, says insurer deserved 12 jurors, not six
JANET ADAMS BROSNAHAN
fields.bio: Janet Adams Brosnahan was first elected to the Circuit Court in 2002. She is currently assigned to the law division and was previously assigned to the fifth municipal district. Before becoming a judge, she was an associate at several local law firms for 12 years. She is on the board of Women Everywhere, a nonprofit service organization formed by judges and attorneys that aims to create opportunities for women and children in need.
fields.notable:
Brosnahan’s husband, James Brosnahan, is one of several former Illinois state representatives turned lobbyists, whose clients have included AT&T and Exelon, the parent company of Commonwealth Edison. In July, the Chicago Tribune [reported that AT&T had been subpoenaed](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/criminal-justice/ct-michael-madigan-att-federal-lobbying-investigation-20200723-ldws3ytverb6hfpknx6n5mjktq-story.html) by federal prosecutors as part of their probe into ComEd’s lobbying practices. Brosnahan has not been accused of wrongdoing.

In an emailed statement, Judge Brosnahan wrote, "My spouse's former and current occupations and/or his former and current clients have no bearing on my qualifications to continue serving as a circuit court judge – a role I've performed with competence, diligence and integrity for almost 18 years. To suggest that the fulfillment of my responsibilities to the citizens of Cook County is somehow related to my husband's career is wrong and patently sexist."

fields.name: THOMAS J. BYRNE
fields.bio: Thomas John Byrne was elected to the Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. He is currently assigned to the criminal division. He spent most of his first judicial term hearing misdemeanor criminal cases in the first municipal district. Before becoming a judge, Byrne worked as a prosecutor in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office for nearly 20 years.
fields.notable:
In 2014, Byrne [denied a certificate of innocence](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-burge-victim-innocence-met-20141016-story.html) for Stanley Wrice, a Chicago police torture survivor who spent more than 30 years in prison before his rape conviction was thrown out by another judge a year earlier. Wrice said detectives John Byrne and Peter Dignan, who worked under former police Cmdr. Jon Burge, had beaten him with a flashlight and rubber hose until he confessed. Byrne concluded that circumstantial evidence and witness testimony “powerfully” pointed to Wrice’s guilt. Earlier this year, [Wrice won $5.2 million](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/after-31-years-in-prison-chicago-man-awarded-5-2-million-in-case-city-bitterly-fought/) in a civil trial against the city of Chicago and the two detectives.

In 2015, Byrne [denied a certificate of innocence](https://chicago.suntimes.com/2016/6/24/18459758/alstory-simon-released-from-prison-denied-certificate-of-innocence) for Alstory Simon, who was exonerated in 2015, after then-Cook County State’s Attorney Anita Alvarez concluded that Simon had been coerced into confessing to a 1982 murder by a private investigator working with the Medill Innocence Project. Byrne ruled that Simon was not eligible for a certificate of innocence because he voluntarily caused his own conviction. His decision was overturned by the Appellate Court in 2017.

In a statement, a spokesperson for Byrne said, "Judge Byrne's ruling [in the Wrice case] was consistent with Judge Walsh's earlier ruling granting Wrice a new trial based on the coerced statement." She also noted that the damages in his civil trial were awarded "for the coerced statement" and not "for an alleged wrongful conviction."

fields.name: No more HOPE: Cook County court program halted after years of problems
general for COOK - 3RD SUBCIRCUIT - MURPHY VACANCY
TERESA MOLINA
fields.bio: Teresa Molina was appointed to a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court in July 2019, and she currently works in the First Municipal Division, where she oversees traffic cases. Prior to her appointment, she led real estate prosecutions at the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation. For the first 15 years of her legal career, Molina was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney, where she worked in the felony trial division, the grand jury unit, and the felony review unit.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Molina’s “significant trial experience” and legal knowledge. The ISBA said, “She received favorable comments regarding her temperament, diligence and integrity.” The CCL noted, “She is considered to be a good jurist in the limited time she has been on the bench.”

fields.name: Illinois appeals court frowns at lineup with one suspect matching description of suspect
TERRENCE J. McGUIRE
fields.bio: Terrence J. McGuire was elected to the Circuit Court in 2014. He is currently assigned to the probate division, hearing cases involving the estates of people who have died. Before becoming a judge, he had a private practice focused on estate planning and real estate transactions. He also served as an administrative law judge for Cook County and the City of Chicago.

fields.name: JAMES PATRICK FLANNERY, JR.
fields.bio: James Patrick Flannery was appointed to the Circuit Court as an associate judge in 1988, and elected circuit judge in 1990. He is currently the presiding judge of the law division, which hears cases involving large monetary damages, a position he has held since 2014. Before becoming a judge, Flannery was an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago for four years and an assistant attorney general for four years, with a brief stint in private practice. In 2017, he was appointed to the Illinois Supreme Court’s commission to reform pretrial practices.
fields.notable: In 2012, Flannery was selected to serve as chairman of the court’s orientation and training program for new judges.

fields.name: Illinois County Wins Fight to Tax Sweetened Drinks
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN KUZAS
Through it all, he kept his job
CCL Well Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has demonstrated the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in the areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character), and excellence in most areas.

fields.name: CHRIS STACEY
fields.bio: Chris Stacey has worked in private practice throughout his legal career, primarily in the areas of tort and commercial litigation. Stacey has run for judge once before, in 1998, when he [highlighted](https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/playing-an-angle/Content?oid=895665) his musical background. He has served on the board of Cabrini Green Legal Aid.
fields.notable: Stacey is the Democratic party’s slated candidate. He has loaned his campaign more than $170,000 and has donated more than $40,000 to the Cook County Democratic Party.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote Stacey is “highly regarded for his knowledge of the law, legal ability, and excellent demeanor.” The ISBA wrote, “Attorneys overwhelmingly praised him for his legal knowledge, intelligence, professionalism, and fairness.” The CCL noted, “He is exceptionally active in community affairs.”

fields.name: Two Cook County judges in ‘judge jail’ want 6 more years on the bench
DANIEL J. KUBASIAK
fields.bio: Daniel J. Kubasiak was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2012 and elected in 2014. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private practice. From 1983 to 1987, he was the chief administrative officer of the Chicago City Council’s Finance Committee. Before becoming a lawyer, he worked in the city’s finance and budget management offices, first appointed under Mayor Richard J. Daley. He is on the board of governors of the Catholic Lawyers Guild of Chicago and the board of directors of the Illinois Lawyers’ Assistance Program, which provides mental health resources to attorneys, judges, and law students.
fields.notable:
After serving as the chief administrative officer for the City Council Finance Committee under Alderman Ed Burke during the ‘Council Wars,’ Kubasiak served as campaign manager for Alderman Ed Vrdolyak’s racist 1987 campaign to unseat Mayor Harold Washington.

In 2017, Kubasiak dismissed a legal challenge to Cook County’s sweetened beverage tax, after initially delaying the tax to allow the lawsuit to proceed. The so-called “soda tax” was later repealed by the county board.

Kubasiak declined to comment.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN SHEAHAN
ANDREA M. BUFORD
fields.bio: Andrea Michele Buford was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2013 and won her seat in the next year’s elections. Before becoming a judge, Buford worked primarily in private practice. She also served as a hearing officer for the Illinois Board of Education and the Illinois Department of Human Services. From 2017 to 2018, Buford chaired the Illinois Judicial Council, a historically African-American judicial organization with the mission of educating communities about the legal system.

fields.name: Big Big Loss For Food Trucks As Judge Calls Gripes About City Rules 'Absurd'
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN ARAUJO
P. SCOTT NEVILLE, JR.
fields.bio: Neville was appointed to the Illinois Supreme Court in 2018, following the retirement of Charles Freeman, the only person of color ever to win election to a seat on the state’s highest court. Neville was first appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1999 and elected the following year. In 2004, he was appointed to the Illinois Appellate Court, and he won election to that seat in 2012. Prior to becoming a judge, Neville spent years in private practice, and for several years one of his partners was Nathaniel Howse, now a competitor for the Supreme Court seat. Last year Neville authored the opinion for a unanimous state Supreme Court ruling that sentences of more than 40 years for juveniles are effectively life sentences, triggering additional protections for youth.
fields.notable: As a Supreme Court justice, Neville has taken an active role to ensure all courtrooms provide a means to transcribe proceedings and in protecting the rights of litigants who are in court without a lawyer.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations praised Neville’s experience and legal knowledge. The CBA said he is “committed to improving the Illinois Courts.” The ISBA said his questions during oral arguments reflect a thorough review of the briefs and that he is considered to be “honest and a straight shooter.” The CCL cited praise from “social justice advocates” and Neville’s “understanding that judges can be active supporters of reforms aimed at improving the effectiveness and fairness of our courts.”

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN RAINES
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN ROSS
Cook County Democrats drop two judges from retention endorsement
JONATHAN CLARK GREEN
fields.bio: Jonathan Clark Green is a supervising attorney in the Chicago Department of Law who focuses on civil litigation. Green was first licensed in Illinois in 1986, and has been in his current position since 2003. He has worked on implementing the city’s new consent decree for police officers, and represented the city and police in lawsuits. Previously, Green was an assistant attorney general in the office of the Illinois Attorney General.
fields.notable: Green’s division of the Law Department has in the past been criticized and sanctioned for withholding evidence in lawsuits against the city police. *Injustice Watch* [reported on those complaints](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2018/chicago-law-department-police-running-for-judge-accused-of-withholding-evidence/) in 2018, when Green previously ran for a Circuit Court seat. Green responded that he has never been personally sanctioned by any court and says he was not personally involved in the particular discovery issues that we previously reported on.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and CCL praised Green’s broad legal experience and his legal ability. The ISBA wrote that a few attorneys “expressed concerns over ongoing discovery issues in federal court in civil rights cases with the City’s Law Department, and his role and responsibility concerning those issues.”

fields.name: Judge won't unlock Valerie Percy murder file; says investigation is "active" after 50 years
JILL ROSE QUINN
fields.bio: Jill Quinn is an attorney in private practice, working in a wide range of areas of law, including bankruptcy, family law, and criminal defense. Before running her own practice, Quinn worked for the Village Attorney of Glen Ellyn and as an arbitrator in both DuPage and Cook counties. She ran unsuccessfully for a Cook County Circuit Court 10th subcircuit seat in 2018.
fields.notable: If elected, Quinn would become the first transgender judge in Illinois.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL touted Quinn’s “substantial litigation experience in more complex legal areas,” and the CBA noted her “outstanding demeanor and temperament.” The ISBA said, “She has limited criminal jury experience but many civil bench trials and has handled some appellate matters.”

fields.name: ROBERT D. KUZAS
fields.bio: Robert D. Kuzas was elected to the Circuit Court in 2014 and hears misdemeanor criminal cases in branch 43 on the West Side of Chicago. Before becoming a judge, Kuzas worked in private practice doing criminal defense, personal injury, and labor relations work, including representing the Chicago Police Sergeants Association. Before becoming an attorney, Kuzas was a Chicago police officer, and he also served as the 46th Ward Democratic Committeeman.
fields.notable:
Before running for judge, Kuzas lived in a condo on Lake Shore Drive in the Lakeview neighborhood. Two months before a seat opened up in the seventh subcircuit, which covers much of the West Side of Chicago, Kuzas leased an apartment on the eastern edge of the district and changed his voter registration, the [Chicago Sun-Times reported](https://chicago.suntimes.com/2014/10/6/18437976/how-a-white-police-attorney-got-a-west-side-judge-seat). Records show he sold the Lakeview condo in 2019.

In 2017, Kuzas [acquitted](https://graphics.chicagotribune.com/chicago-public-schools-sexual-abuse/cruz) a Chicago Public Schools security guard of misdemeanor battery charges, after two female students accused him of gropping them. Before handing down the not-guilty verdict, the Chicago Tribune reported, Kuzas told the guard: “I’m really, really disturbed with you. I really am. It’s just shocking that two young girls would come forward and make these allegations against you without it being somewhere, some semblance of truth to it.”

Kuzas declined to comment.

fields.name: JOHN J. MAHONEY
fields.bio: John Mahoney was elected to the Circuit Court of Cook County in 2014, and currently serves in the fifth municipal district in Bridgeview. Before becoming a judge, he was a supervisor in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office, overseeing the public corruption and financial crimes unit. Mahoney spent more than 24 years in two different stints as an assistant state’s attorney, working in numerous divisions, including the juvenile justice, insurance fraud, and felony trial divisions. In between his stints at the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office, he worked for six years as an attorney for Peoples Energy Corporation.
fields.notable: Mahoney was among a handful of assistant state’s attorneys interviewed by special prosecutor Dan K. Webb during a review of the Chicago Police Department and Cook County State’s Attorney’s office’s investigation into David Koschman’s death, [according to the Chicago Sun-Times](http://projects.suntimes.com/koschman/latest-news/from-koschman-case-to-seats-on-the-bench/). A nephew of former Mayor Richard M. Daley was eventually charged and later pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA said "concerns were raised” during their evaluation about Mahoney’s “arrogance and a lack of sensitivity to diversity issues."

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN POWELL
general for COOK - 3RD SUBCIRCUIT - FLYNN VACANCY
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN T. McGUIRE
CCL Not Recommended
fields.description: The candidate refused to submit their credentials, but the council is not aware of credible information that would justify a “not qualified” rating.

fields.name: As it overturns conviction, Illinois appeals court chastises Cook County judge
general for COOK - 10TH SUBCIRCUIT - ALLEN VACANCY
Former public defender
fields.description: History as a public defender is an important qualification in terms of experience. According to Professor Tonja Jacobi, who studies judicial politics at Northwestern University's Pritzker School of Law, former defense attorneys may be more likely to be more sympathetic to defendants in criminal cases.

fields.name: STEVEN G. WATKINS
fields.bio: Steven G. Watkins was elected to the Circuit Court in 2014 and hears cases in the criminal division. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private practice, focused on criminal defense, civil litigation, and real estate. He also served as an arbitrator with the Cook County Circuit Court’s Mandatory Arbitration Program.
fields.notable:
Watkins initially ran for a seat in the 3rd subcircuit on the Southwest Side in 2010, but lost in a six-way primary. In 2014, he ran for a seat in the 2nd subcircuit, on the South Side, using an address in Longwood Manor that he didn’t own, [the Better Government Association reported](https://www.bettergov.org/news/judgment-call/). Property records show he purchased a house in the 2nd subcircuit in 2018. Watkins declined to comment.

In May 2019, Watkins [allowed](https://abcnews.go.com/US/illinois-judge-orders-records-empire-actor-jussie-smollett/story?id=63233537) records in the original criminal case against former “Empire” actor Jussie Smollett to be unsealed.

fields.name: general for COOK - 6TH SUBCIRCUIT - NEGA VACANCY
general for COOK CIRCUIT- MURPHY GORMAN VACANCY
MICHAEL P. TOOMIN
fields.bio: Michael P. Toomin was selected as an associate judge in 1980 and won election as a circuit judge in 1984. He spent the first part of his career as a judge hearing felony criminal cases in the criminal division. From 2008 to 2010, he served by appointment on the Illinois Appellate Court. In 2010, Chief Judge Timothy Evans appointed him to his current post as presiding judge of the juvenile justice division, which hears cases of youth charged with crimes. Before becoming a judge, Toomin was a Cook County assistant public defender and also worked in private practice doing criminal defense. He has served on or chaired numerous commissions or boards, including the Illinois Courts Commission, which hears disciplinary cases against judges, and an Illinois Supreme Court special committee on capital cases.
fields.notable:
Toomin is one of two judges the Cook County Democratic Party [voted not to endorse for retention](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/judicial-elections/2020/cook-county-democrats-retention-toomin-araujo/) this year. Evanston Township Committeeman Eamon Kelly, who chaired the party’s judicial retention committee, said his committee’s recommendation was based on “voices of juvenile justice advocates, law professors, foundation leaders, legal aid attorneys who described him as imperial...not collaborative and said he has obstructed efforts to reform the criminal justice system."

Earlier this year, Toomin [came under fire](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/judge-blocks-key-legal-protection-for-detained-youth/) for making it harder for juveniles seeking release from detention during the coronavirus pandemic. Last year, [he ruled](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appellate-court-rejects-ordinance-banning-detention-of-10-12-year-olds/) that an ordinance passed unanimously by the Cook County Board of Commissioners banning the detention of youth under 13 was invalid because it conflicted with Illinois law. His ruling was upheld on appeal.

In September, [Injustice Watch reported](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/judicial-elections/2020/table-of-wisdom-toomin-burke/) that Toomin had taken part in an investment club with other judges and attorneys, including indicted Alderman Ed Burke.

Toomin has also presided over several high-profile cases, including the manslaughter case against former Mayor Richard M. Daley’s nephew, R.J. Vanecko, in the death of David Koschman, and the case against former “Empire” star Jussie Smollett. In a statement, a spokesperson for Toomin alleged that the Democratic Party’s “no” vote was retaliation for Toomin’s criticism of Cook County State’s Attorney Kim Foxx’s handling of the Smollett case.

fields.name: PATRICIA MANILA MARTIN
fields.bio: Patricia Manila Martin was elected to the Circuit Court in 1996. She has served as the presiding judge of the child protection division since 2000. Before becoming a judge, she spent her career as a Cook County assistant public defender. She has previously served as the president of the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges. In 2013, former President Barack Obama appointed her to the Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities.
fields.notable: Martin has said that she plans to retire from the bench at the end of her term in December, even if she wins retention.
fields.ratingNotes: Martin did not participate in the bar association ratings process.

fields.name: Jail Roulette: Cook County's arbitrary bond court system
DEBRA B. WALKER
fields.bio: Debra B. Walker was first elected to the Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. Before becoming a judge, she was a litigator specializing in defending malpractice lawsuits. She also represented judges before the Judicial Inquiry Board, which investigates judicial misconduct. She has served on the Illinois Supreme Court Commission on Professionalism since 2001 and was the commission’s chair from 2013 to 2019.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN O'HARA
Negative ratings
fields.description: Bar associations provide some of the most unbiased information for assessing the qualifications of potential judges. These bodies interview candidates and assess their personal and professional histories. They also ask judges and attorneys who have worked with or appeared before the candidates about their temperament and professionalism. Ratings are based on qualifications, not political views, and negative ratings are a strong signal that a candidate could make a poor judge. Candidates who choose not to participate in the ratings process automatically receive negative ratings.

fields.name: Illinois appeals court: Chicago police cannot decide on probable cause without judicial review
Sham candidates for judge: an election secret you’re not supposed to know about
Too close? Cook County judge asks millions in fees for prior legal work; Defendants: Judge's colleagues can't rule
DIANA ROSARIO
fields.bio: Diana Rosario was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014. She currently serves in the domestic relations division. Before becoming a judge, she was an attorney for the City of Chicago’s Department of Family and Support Services and an Administrative Hearing Officer for the city’s Department of Aviation. Before that, she was an assistant state’s attorney in the civil division. Rosario is the secretary of the Illinois Latino Judges Association and on the board of the Puerto Rican Bar Association of Illinois.
fields.notable: Rosario was found “not qualified” by the Chicago Council of Lawyers in her run for the bench in 2014. The council was concerned she did not have enough experience in complex litigation.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA said, "Some attorneys raised concerns about rulings that were inconsistent with the law, her ability to hear complex cases, and timeliness at issuing written orders, while other(s) described her ability as adequate."

fields.name: MARY ELLEN COGHLAN
fields.bio: Mary Ellen Coghlan was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1995 and was elected the following year. She has been serving on the Illinois Appellate Court by assignment since July 2019. Before that appointment, Coghlan served as the presiding judge of the probate division. Before becoming a judge, Coghlan was a Cook County assistant public defender for five years and an Illinois assistant attorney general for eight years. Coghlan is currently a member of the Judicial Inquiry Board, which evaluates disciplinary complaints against judges. She is also on the Circuit Court’s nominating committee for associate judges.
fields.notable:
In 2002, Coghlan [sentenced two Chicago police officers](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2002-05-10-0205100371-story.html) to 18 months probation and ordered them to pay $1,500 fines after they were found guilty of obstructing a police officer for lying to a supervisor about a car crash that happened while they were on duty. The guilty plea helped them avoid felony official misconduct charges, which allowed them to potentially keep their police pensions.

In 1996, Coghlan acquitted a man of drug charges after two Chicago police officers gave conflicting testimony about whether the man had dropped drugs as the officer approached. The officer who claimed he saw the man drop drugs was later arrested by federal agents on corruption charges. 

Coghlan’s cousin is former Cook County Judge Matthew Coghlan, who lost his seat in 2018 after becoming the first Cook County judge in 28 years to lose a retention bid.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN ARCE
CHRIS LAWLER
fields.bio: Chris Lawler was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2013, and ran for election in 2014. He currently hears civil cases in the law division. Before becoming a judge, Lawler was a personal injury and insurance defense lawyer for 25 years.
fields.notable: Earlier this year, the Illinois Appellate Court overturned a decision by Lawler to dismiss a defamation case filed by Paul Ciolino, the former private investigator for the Medill Innocence Project, whose role in the confession of Alstory Simon for a 1982 murder in Washington Park has been the subject of numerous articles, a book, a documentary, lawsuits, and counter-suits. Lawler had ruled that the defamation claim was barred by the statute of limitations.

fields.name: PAMELA McLEAN MEYERSON
fields.bio: Pamela McLean Meyerson was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2013 and elected in 2014. She is assigned to the chancery division, where she hears a variety of civil cases, including minor disputes, class-action lawsuits, and reviews of administrative decisions made by state and municipal agencies. Before becoming a judge, Meyerson was an attorney in private practice, handling civil litigation and business transactions.
fields.notable:
Before her appointment in 2013, Meyerson lost judicial elections in 2010 and 2012. She ran unopposed in 2014.

Meyerson is presiding over an ongoing class-action lawsuit that contends the City of Chicago illegally sent distracted driving tickets to its administrative hearing department instead of traffic court. In 2018, Meyerson denied a motion by the city to dismiss the lawsuit, allowing it to move forward.

fields.name: ANN COLLINS-DOLE
fields.bio: Before she was elected to the bench in 2008, Ann Collins-Dole was chief assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago. She spent 17 years in various roles in the city’s law department. She received her law degree from Loyola University Chicago in 1990. Prior to becoming a lawyer, she was an arts administrator at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

fields.name: REGINA ANN MESCALL
fields.bio: Regina Ann Mescall has worked as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney since 2007. She currently oversees cases as a first chair felony trial assistant, responsible for the active murder cases in Cook County. Mescall began her career as an assistant district attorney in Albuquerque, New Mexico, where she prosecuted crimes against children for over 5 years.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Mescall’s “extensive experience” and noted that she has tried “many high profile cases.” The ISBA also praised her experience in “serious and complex felonies.” The CCL wrote that she “is considered to have good legal ability and handles some of the most complex matters in the State’s Attorney’s Office.”

fields.name: PERLA TIRADO
fields.currentJob: Supervising attorney at Beyond Legal Aid
fields.bio: Perla Tirado began her career with the Cook County Public Defender’s office, where she defended cases related to traffic violations and domestic violence. She then went into private practice, specializing in criminal defense and immigration law. Tirado currently works as a supervising attorney at Beyond Legal Aid, a non-profit legal aid organization for underserved communities.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL said Tirado has a good temperament and “substantial litigation experience in a variety of areas.” But the CBA and ISBA raised concerns about her lack of experience with complex litigation.

fields.name: ANTHONY C. "TONY" KYRIAKOPOULOS
fields.bio: Anthony C. “Tony” Kyriakopoulos was first appointed to the Circuit Court in 2010. He hears mechanic’s liens cases in the chancery division. Before becoming a judge, Kyriakopoulos was an assistant state’s attorney for 20 years, including in the money laundering unit of the narcotics division. He serves on the board of the Hellenic Bar Association of Illinois.
fields.notable: Kyriakopoulos is one of several judges who were reappointed to the bench by the Illinois Supreme Court after stepping aside so a Democratic Party favorite could win election. After being appointed in 2010, he filed to run in 2012 against former Chicago Alderman Tom Allen (38th). After he withdrew from the race, Kyriakopoulos was reappointed to another seat. He won election for the first time in 2014. Kyriakopoulous declined to comment.

fields.name: BRIDGET ANNE MITCHELL
fields.bio: Bridget Anne Mitchell was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014. Before becoming a judge, she worked in private practice, handling medical malpractice and wrongful death cases. She received her bachelor’s degree from the University of Illinois and her law degree from Chicago-Kent College of Law.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN LOZA
URSULA WALOWSKI
fields.bio: Ursula Walowski was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. She currently hears cases in the criminal division, and has previously served in the domestic violence division. Before becoming a judge, she spent 14 years as a Cook County assistant state’s attorney.

fields.name: Restorative Justice Court Coming to Englewood
MAURA McMAHON ZELLER
fields.bio: Maura Zeller has been an attorney in Cook County for over 26 years, primarily in the area of child welfare and guardianship litigation. She currently represents children in child custody cases as an appointed child representative and guardian ad litem. Before that, she worked for a decade in the Office of the Public Guardian as an assistant public guardian and child representative. Zeller is the board chair of the Thrive Counseling Center in Oak Park.
fields.ratingNotes: Ratings for McMahon were mixed. The CCL rated Zeller qualified for her substantial litigation experience, although noted her “area of practice is narrow.” The CBA pointed to Zeller’s “excellent temperament.” The ISBA cited “concerns about the depth and breadth of her overall legal experience.”

fields.name: CAROLINE KATE MORELAND
fields.bio: Caroline Kate Moreland was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2010. Before becoming a judge, Moreland was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney for 14 years.
fields.notable:
Moreland is one of several judges who were reappointed to the bench by the Illinois Supreme Court after stepping aside so a Democratic Party favorite could win election, [the Chicago Tribune reported](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-met-supreme-judges-20121223-story.html). In 2012, she filed to run against Michael T. Mullen, who had donated $30,000 to the Democratic Party, but then withdrew and was appointed to a different vacancy. She ran unopposed in 2014.

In 2020, Moreland [dismissed a lawsuit](https://news.wttw.com/2020/05/19/judge-tosses-suit-challenging-dcfs-ban-supervised-person-visits-during-pandemic) filed by Cook County Public Defender Amy Campanelli that sought to lift a ban on supervised in-person visits for children in foster care and their parents during the coronavirus pandemic.

Moreland declined to comment.

fields.name: LEVANDER "VAN" SMITH, JR.
fields.bio:
Levander Smith was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in early 2019 and currently oversees cases in the domestic violence division. Late last year, Smith was elected by the Circuit Court judges to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the Circuit Court seat open until the election; Smith is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

Prior to his appointment to the bench, he had two stints as an attorney with the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services, first in the 1990s and then again from 2011 to 2019. In between, he spent four years as a prosecutor, first in St. Louis County and then in Cook County. He was also an assistant attorney general in Missouri, where he worked on worker’s compensation cases.
fields.notable: His campaign is mostly self-funded. He had loaned his campaign over $60,000 as of Dec. 31, 2019. He is the Democratic party’s slated candidate and he has donated $30,000 to the Cook County Democractic Party.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Smith’s “varied practice experience” and work ethic. The ISBA wrote that Smith “has an excellent understanding of the law, is sensitive to all, punctual, diligent, and fair.” The CCL complemented his good temperament and trial skills.

fields.name: 2nd Subcircuit
fields.description: The 2nd subcircuit includes the South Side neighborhoods of Roseland and Pullman and several south suburbs, including Dolton, Riverdale, Dixmoor, Harvey, and Homewood. It is home to the court's Markham Courthouse.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN HANSEN
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN FELICE
2 officers cop plea, get probation and fine
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN MORELAND
ANJANA HANSEN
fields.bio: Anjana Hansen was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014. She currently hears misdemeanor and traffic cases in the second municipal district in Skokie. Before becoming a judge, Hansen was an administrative hearing officer for the City of Evanston. She served as an alderman in Evanston from 2005 to 2009. Before that, Hansen was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney for 12 years, where she served in several positions, including the juvenile justice, felony review, and felony trial divisions.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN CURRY
MICHAEL B. HYMAN
fields.bio: Michael B. Hyman was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2006 and won election in 2008. Since 2013, he has served by appointment on the Illinois Appellate Court. Before becoming a judge, Hyman spent 27 years in private practice. He has previously served as president of the Chicago Bar Association and first vice-president of the Illinois Judges Association. He is the editor-in-chief of the bar association magazine, the CBA Record, for which he regularly writes.
fields.notable:
Hyman is running unopposed for a permanent seat on the Appellate Court after winning the Democratic primary in March. Another candidate in that race, Maureen O’Leary, was accused of being a “sham candidate,” placed on the ballot to help Hyman, who was the Democratic party’s pick for the seat. Hyman denied any involvement in O’Leary’s bid. 
Hyman has often written opinions siding with the rights of the accused. Last October, he [dissented when an appellate panel](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appellate-court-rejects-ordinance-banning-detention-of-10-12-year-olds/) ruled that Judge Michael Toomin, who is also running for retention, could order the detention of a 12-year old, despite a county ordinance that forbade such detentions. In the past two years, Hyman has authored opinions for divided courts striking down a conviction that followed a lineup [made suspect by](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appeals-court-frowns-at-lineup-with-one-suspect-matching-description/) the defendant’s clothing; a gun conviction that followed a police search that [lacked sufficient cause](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/in-two-cases-illinois-appeals-judges-split-on-protections-in-criminal-cases/); and challenged the constitutionality of Chicago police arrests based on “[investigative alerts](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appeals-court-chicago-police-cannot-decide-on-probable-cause-without-judicial-review/).”

fields.name: AURELIA MARIE PUCINSKI
fields.bio: Aurelia Pucinski was elected to the Appellate Court in 2010. Before that, she served for six years as a Circuit Court judge, primarily in the domestic violence division. She has served in numerous elected and appointed positions throughout her lengthy career in public service, including stints as Clerk of the Circuit Court, Metropolitan Water Reclamation District commissioner, director of the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation, and chairman of the Illinois Environmental Regulatory Review Commission. She has also worked as an attorney in the City of Chicago law department, the U.S. Small Business Administration, and private practice.
fields.notable:
In 2010, the Chicago Council of Lawyers found her unqualified for a seat on the Appellate Court. In 2019, she joined a decision ruling that Chicago Police ‘investigative alerts’ were unconstitutional.

Pucinski is also part of a well-connected political family. Her father was a U.S. Congressman and longtime alderman for Chicago’s 41st ward who voted as part of the white ethnic bloc during the ‘Council Wars’ of the 1980s, when Chicago’s first Black mayor, Harold Washington, was in office. Pucinski has sought higher positions in public office throughout her career. In 1986, Pucinski ran an unsuccessful campaign for Illinois Secretary of State. In 1997, Pucinski switched to the Republican Party to challenge Cook County Board President John H. Stroger Jr., but was defeated in the 1998 general election. In 2012, she ran unsuccessfully for the Illinois Supreme Court.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN WALOWSKI
SONDRA NICOLE DENMARK
fields.bio: Sondra Denmark was appointed to the 2nd subcircuit in December of 2018, and currently oversees municipal cases at the Daley Center. She previously worked as an assistant state’s attorney for 13 years, ten of those years in Will County and three in Cook County. Denmark ran unsuccessfully for a 15th subcircuit vacancy in 2014.
fields.ratingNotes: The bar associations all praised Denmark’s litigation experience, legal ability and temperament. The ISBA praised her for her “professionalism, preparation and fairness.”

fields.name: Alstory Simon, released from prison, denied ‘certificate of innocence’
PATRICK KEVIN COUGHLIN
fields.bio: Patrick Kevin Coughlin was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014, where he currently hears felony cases in the sixth municipal district in Markham. Before becoming a judge, Coughlin was a career prosecutor, serving in various roles in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office for 18 years, including deputy bureau chief of the narcotics division.
fields.notable:
In 2012, as an assistant state’s attorney, Coughlin [opposed a bill](https://www.saukvalley.com/2012/02/09/bill-would-legalize-recording-cops-in-public/ap3icxg/) to change Illinois’ strict eavesdropping law to allow the recording of police officers while they were on duty. Coughlin told a local newspaper that the bill would unfairly favor civilian rights over police officers. The bill failed, but the Illinois Supreme Court [ruled](https://www.illinoispolicy.org/illinois-supreme-court-strikes-down-eavesdropping-law/) the eavesdropping law unconstitutional in 2014, and it was amended later that year.

In an emailed statement, Coughlin said he was representing the position of the Cook County State's Attorney's Office that Illinois should become a one-party consent state, allowing any member of a conversation to record it, regardless of whether they were law enforcement officers or civilians. He also said he testified in support of the use of police body-worn cameras before a legislative committee in 2014.

6th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 6th subcircuit extends northwest from West Town through Hermosa and north to Ravenswood. It also includes Wicker Park, Bucktown, Logan Square, Avondale and part of Humboldt Park.

Past controversy

fields.name: I have to make this right
DIANA L. KENWORTHY
fields.bio: Diana L. Kenworthy was elected to the Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. Kenworthy currently hears cases in the criminal division. Before that, she spent nine years in the domestic violence division. Before becoming a judge, she spent four years as a Cook County assistant public defender and eight years as a partner at Jester, Kenworthy & Eagle LLC, practicing criminal defense law.
fields.notable: In February, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot and interim police chief Charlie Beck [criticized Kenworthy](https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2020/2/21/21144737/charlie-beck-chicago-police-cop-shooting-bail-judge-diana-kenworthy-bryce-jones-lanum-fernando-soto) for granting bond to a 22-year-old who had been held in Cook County Jail without bail for almost a year on charges of attempted murder of a police officer.

fields.name: Here’s what passes for “beyond a reasonable doubt” in a gang murder case
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN BRENNAN
general for COOK - 2ND SUBCIRCUIT - A VACANCY
MEGAN ELIZABETH GOLDISH
fields.bio: Megan Goldish was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014 and currently hears cases in the domestic violence division. Before becoming a judge, she was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney for 17 years, mostly in the felony trial division. She is a board member of several bar associations, including the North Suburban Bar Association of Illinois, the Decalogue Society, and the Jewish Judges Association. She also serves on the boards of several nonprofit organizations, including Chicago Lighthouse for the Blind, the Lynn Sage Cancer Research Foundation, and Bright Star Community Outreach.
fields.notable: A pending civil lawsuit [accuses Goldish](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/judge-goldish-velez-case/) of helping to convict a Chicago teen of murder nearly two decades ago based on witness statesments that were allegedly false and coerced by police. The lawsuit alleges that Goldish, then a prosecutor on the case, either helped coordinate the statement with cops or that the officers kept the alleged scheme concealed from Goldish. The witness later recanted her statement and the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office vacated the conviction in 2017. Goldish has denied any wrongdoing.

fields.name: Cook County judge resigns, avoiding discipline for alleged sexual harassment
KRISTAL RIVERS
fields.bio: Kristal Rivers was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in June 2014, before winning election that November. She currently hears cases in the juvenile justice division. Rivers started her legal career as a prosecutor for the Dallas County Prosecutor’s Office in Texas. From 2001 to 2010, she had a private practice focused on real estate and civil litigation. Before becoming a judge, she was an assistant attorney general in the Sexually Violent Persons Bureau of the Illinois Attorney General’s Office. She is a member of the Illinois Supreme Court’s committee on equality, and has been on the boards of the Cook County Bar Association, the Illinois Judges Foundation, and WINGS, Inc., which provides services and advocacy for survivors of domestic violence.
fields.notable: Rivers has been reversed several times since 2014 by appeals courts for ordering juveniles she sentenced to probation to clear their social media of any signs of gang or drug activity, which [some courts have ruled were too broad](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-met-juvenile-social-media-use-20180403-story.html) and violated the defendants’ freedom of speech. Other appellate panels have upheld the social media restrictions.
