FBI grilled Cook County judge with ties to indicted Chicago cop
CELESTIA L. MAYS
fields.bio:
Celestia Mays was appointed to a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court at the end of 2018 and began hearing cases in the Municipal Division in January 2019.  She served in this position until late last year, when she was elected by the Circuit Court judges to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the Circuit Court seat open until the election; Mays is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

Prior to her appointment, she focused on family and estate law as an attorney in private practice. Mays also previously served as the president of the Cook County Bar Association. She was a finalist for an associate judgeship in 2018, but she was not selected.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Mays “is hardworking and receives high marks for her fine temperament and people skills.” The CCL noted she is an “excellent practitioner with great integrity” who is “exceptionally active in community activities.” The ISBA commended Mays for her professionalism, diligence and temperament.

fields.name: general for COOK - 12TH SUBCIRCUIT - HANLON VACANCY
JOHN MICHAEL ALLEGRETTI
fields.bio: John Michael Allegretti was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014, where he currently hears civil cases in the first municipal district in Chicago. Before becoming a judge he worked as general counsel in both the Cook County Treasurer’s Office and the Cook County Assessor’s Office; as an assistant state’s attorney in the torts, taxation, and civil rights divisions; and as an administrative law judge for the Illinois Property Tax Appeal Board. He also has experience in private practice as an associate at several law firms and corporate counsel for a real estate management company. He is a former Riverside Township Democratic Committeeman.
fields.notable: As a Cook County assistant state’s attorney, Allegretti defended the Cook County Sheriff’s Office and individual correctional officers in civil rights lawsuits. He ran unsuccessfully for judge in 2008 before winning his seat in 2014.

fields.name: LAURA MARIE SULLIVAN
fields.bio: Laura Marie Sullivan was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2002. She currently hears felony preliminary hearings in branch 38 of the first municipal district in Chicago. She previously served in felony bond court and in the domestic violence division. Before becoming a judge, Sullivan was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney.
fields.notable:
In 2014, a law professor criticized Sullivan after a courtroom deputy barred him from taking notes while observing her courtroom. In her years spent overseeing bond court, Sullivan, along with other bond judges, set high bonds even when pre-trial assessments determined that someone was at low risk of reoffending, [according to an Injustice Watch investigation](https://www.injusticewatch.org/interactives/jail-roulette/). In an emailed statement, Sullivan said she set bonds "in accordance with the law/state statute."

Sullivan has donated $4,350 since 2004 to the campaign fund of indicted Chicago Alderman Ed Burke. Burke’s former law firm, Klafter & Burke, has successfully appealed Sullivan’s property tax assessments every year since 2008.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN ROMANEK
PAMELA REAVES-HARRIS
fields.currentJob: Special assistant for legal affairs at the Cook County Bureau of Economic Development
fields.bio: Pamela Reaves-Harris works for the Cook County Bureau of Economic Development as a special assistant for legal affairs. She served as a state representative for the 10th District in the Illinois General Assembly from 2015 to 2017. Prior to her time as a legislator, she worked as a private attorney and as an administrative law judge.
fields.notable: This seat on the 7th subcircuit is being temporarily filled by Cook County Sheriff’s policy director Cara Smith, who was appointed to the seat by the Supreme Court. Smith decided not to run for the seat after Reaves-Harris, among others, labeled Smith’s appointment a snub, because Smith is white and the 7th subcircuit is “a majority-minority district,” [according](https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2019/7/26/8932096/pamela-reaves-harris-cook-county-circuit-court-anne-burke-west-side-chicago-laura-washington) to the Chicago Sun-Times. Reaves-Harris praised Smith’s decision not to run, saying that “this seat was created with the intent to give African Americans in that community representation in the judicial system.”
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL and ISBA highlighted her community service and temperament but noted some concerns about her lack of litigation experience. The CBA praised her legal knowledge and “fine demeanor.”

fields.name: MARY KATHERINE ROCHFORD
fields.bio: Mary Katherine Rochford has served on the Appellate Court since her election in 2010. She was first appointed to the bench as an associate judge in 1991, and was elected as a circuit judge in 2006. Before becoming a judge, Rochford worked in the City of Chicago Law Department in various roles, eventually serving as chief assistant corporation counsel in 1985.
fields.notable: In 2018, Rochford wrote an opinion [throwing out](https://cookcountyrecord.com/stories/511365466-chicago-appeals-court-yanks-14-million-award-v-ismie-says-insurer-deserved-12-jurors-not-six) a $14 million jury award in a medical malpractice suit because the case was heard by a jury of six people under a short-lived state law that was overturned by the Illinois Supreme Court. In 2017, she joined a unanimous opinion denying an appeal for a man convicted of murder despite an eyewitness who recanted his testimony and whose identification appeared to be [contradicted](https://www.injusticewatch.org/commentary/2019/heres-what-passes-for-beyond-a-reasonable-doubt-in-a-gang-murder-case/) by surveillance video. Rochford is the niece of former Chicago Police Supt. James Rochford, who served under Mayor Richard J. Daley, according to the [Chicago Tribune](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1991-01-17-9101050444-story.html).

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN ROSARIO
CCL Highly Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has demonstrated excellence in the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in all areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character).

fields.name: general for COOK CIRCUIT- MASON VACANCY
EILEEN MARIE O'CONNOR
fields.bio: Eileen Marie O'Connor has been an attorney in private practice, with a focus on personal injury, since she was admitted to the bar in 2006. In 2010, she joined her family’s law firm, the O’Connor Law firm, where she currently practices.
fields.notable: O’Connor has represented clients in several civil rights cases, including the family of Tyler Lumar, a young man who died in 2018 from injuries suffered in a suicide attempt while in Chicago police custody. Policle officers had arrested him in a mixup over a warrant issued by Lee County authorities over a $25 parking ticket that he had in fact paid.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL noted O’Connor’s experience in “complex legal matters,” her work ethic, and her pro bono work, and the CBA praised her legal knowledge and demeanor. The ISBA wrote, “Attorneys consider her professional, level-headed and prepared.”

fields.name: RAUL VEGA
fields.bio: Raul Vega was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2002. He was appointed as the presiding judge of the domestic violence division in 2018. Before that, he spent 16 years hearing divorce and child custody cases in the domestic relations division. Before becoming a judge, Vega was an attorney in private practice for nearly 20 years, with a broad practice that included civil litigation, real estate, family law, and bankruptcy, among other areas. He was also a staff attorney for former U.S. Rep. Luis Gutierrez.
fields.notable: In 2013, Vega sealed R. Kelly’s divorce case due to the R&B singer’s celebrity status. That decision was reversed by Judge Lori Rosen last year, after Kelly was indicted on sexual abuse charges.

fields.name: KELLY MARIE McCARTHY
fields.currentJob: Chief of legal resources division of the Cook County Public Defender’s Office
fields.bio: Kelly McCarthy has spent nearly all of her legal career in the Cook County Public Defender’s Office and currently heads the division specializing in appeals and other post-conviction matters. She has worked in several different areas during her time there, including the civil division, the felony trial division and the homicide task force.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised McCarthy’s organizational skills and temperament, the ISBA complemented her complex litigation experience, and the CCL said she is “knowledgeable and hard-working.”

fields.name: MAURICIO ARAUJO
fields.bio:
**Mauricio Araujo has resigned his office, but his name remains on the ballot.**

Mauricio Araujo was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. He had been assigned to the first municipal district, but since 2018, he had been reassigned to administrative duties. Before becoming a judge, Araujo worked for American Family Insurance, mainly doing personal injury defense work. He also worked at the Chicago Housing Authority and the Illinois Attorney General’s Office. He is a past president of the Puerto Rican Bar Association.
fields.notable:
Araujo resigned from the bench, effective Oct. 5.

His resignation [followed a two-day hearing](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/judicial-conduct/2020/state-court-commission-to-discipline-cook-county-judge-accused-of-sexual-harassment/) before the Illinois Courts Commission, which found that there was “clear and convincing evidence” that Araujo engaged in a pattern of inappropriate and harassing behavior toward women.

In 2018, Araujo was put on administrative duty after he was accused of calling a female prosecutor a “bitch” and insinuating that he may have had sex with her. After the Judicial Inquiry Board investigated the matter, two other women came forward with allegations of sexual harassment. A court reporter alleged that Araujo had propositioned her for sex on multiple occasions in 2011 and a Chicago police officer said Araujo tried to kiss her when she came to him to get a warrant approved in 2016.

In September, the Cook County Democratic Committee [voted unanimously](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/judicial-elections/2020/cook-county-democrats-retention-toomin-araujo/) not to endorse Araujo for retention.

Separately, Araujo was called to testify in a corruption case against two Chicago police officers who were ultimately convicted of lying to obtain false search warrants, then stealing cash and drugs they found during raids. Araujo had approved nearly half of the search warrants obtained by the indicted cops’ gang crimes unit over a three-year period, [the Sun-Times reported](https://chicago.suntimes.com/2019/3/29/18361759/fbi-grilled-cook-county-judge-with-ties-to-indicted-chicago-cop).
fields.ratingNotes: Araujo did not participate in the bar association ratings process.

fields.name: LAURA AYALA-GONZALEZ
fields.bio: Laura Ayala-Gonzalez currently works as an superving assistant state's attorney in the felony trial unit of the Cook County State’s Attorney's office. She has spent her entire 16-year legal career in the office, where she has served in the juvenile justice bureau, the gangs and complex homicide unit, and as a deputy supervisor in the felony review unit.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Ayala-Gonzalez is “well regarded by her colleagues” including judges and defense lawyers. The CCL stated that she “has substantial trial experience in complex matters.” The ISBA mentioned that attorneys gave her “high marks for her character and integrity.”

fields.name: Brian Urlacher gets temporary custody of son after boy's stepfather is killed
KENNETH J. WADAS
fields.bio: Kenneth J. Wadas was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1996 and has been assigned to the criminal division since the beginning of his tenure. In 2009, he was appointed a supervising judge within the division. He began his legal career as an assistant state’s attorney for ten years before going into private practice. In 1996, before he was elected to the bench, he was the director of court services for the Circuit Court.
fields.notable:
Wadas has had his decisions reversed by the Illinois Appellate Court 25 times since 2014, more than any other criminal court judge running for retention this year. The appeals court has reversed him for overly harsh sentences, violating the “one act, one crime” doctrine, and assuming a prosecutorial role during trials.

In 1999, he presided over [the trial of Robert Wilson](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2006-11-15-0611150127-story.html), who was charged with attempted murder for allegedly attacking a woman at a bus stop with a box cutter. Wadas prevented Wilson’s attorney from introducing evidence about another man who had confessed to five similar attacks at bus stops in the same area in the two weeks after Wilson was arrested. Wilson was exonerated after almost a decade behind bars.

In 2004, Wadas sentenced Benard McKinley to 100 years in prison for a murder he committed when he was 16. After a federal appeals court determined that Wadas had not adequately considered McKinley’s age in issuing what it called “a certain death sentence,” Wadas [resentenced him to 39 years](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/after-courts-order-new-sentence-cook-county-prisoner-given-39-years-for-murder-committed-as-youth/), just one year less than the number the Illinois Supreme Court has said is an unconstitutional life sentence for a juvenile. Though he was 16 when the crime occurred, Wadas said during the resentencing hearing, “the gun made him older.”

As a prosecutor, Wadas was rebuked by the Appellate Court, calling his trial behavior in one case “an insult to the court and to the dignity of the trial bar," the [Chicago Tribune reported](https://www.chicagotribune.com/investigations/chi-020103trial5-story.html). Wadas declined to comment.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN FLANNERY
1st Subcircuit
fields.description: The 1st subcircuit includes parts of the south and southeast sides of Chicago, including Chatham, South Chicago, East Side and Hegewisch, as well as the south suburbs of Burnham and Calumet City.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN BYRNE
general for COOK - 6TH SUBCIRCUIT - PANTLE VACANCY
ANNA HELEN DEMACOPOULOS
fields.bio: Before becoming a judge, Anna Helen Deacopoulos was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney for more than 20 years. Her previous judicial assignments include the domestic violence division and the sixth municipal district in Markham, where she heard felony, misdemeanor, and traffic cases.
fields.notable:
In 2016, Demacopoulos ruled in favor of a City of Chicago ordinance that restricted how close food trucks could park to brick-and-mortar restaurants. In 2017, she ruled that Sam Cirone, a Chicago Police sergeant who faced discipline for his role in the David Koschman case, could have his case heard by an independent arbitrator, instead of the Chicago Police Board. An appellate court later reversed that decision. Demacopoulos has had 14 decisions reversed by higher courts since 2014, among the most of any of the judges running for retention this year.

In an emailed statement, Demacopoulos said the Appellate Court decision in the Cirone case "has no precedential value and is not binding on any court, rendering it meaningless." She disputed Injustice Watch's accounting of her reversals and said they represent a tiny fraction of the more than 5,000 cases she has heard since 2011. "Comparing judges’ reversals is unfair, challenges the independence of the judiciary and only further discourages judges from taking on difficult assignments in fear of reprisal," she said.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN KUBASIAK
MARGARET ANN BRENNAN
fields.bio: Margaret Ann Brennan was elected to the Circuit Court in 2002. She is currently the supervising judge for the commercial calendar section of the law division. Before becoming a judge, Brennan worked as an attorney for Exelon Business Services. Before that, she was an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago and an associate at a general practice law firm.
fields.notable:
Brennan’s decisions have been reversed by appeals courts 40 times since 2014, the most of any judge running for retention this year. The number of reversals are significantly higher even than her counterparts in the law division. Many of these reversals revolve around Brennan’s decision to dismiss a lawsuit before it goes to trial, in a ruling known as “summary judgment.”

Last year, Brennan [imposed more than $1 million in sanctions](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/us-law-week/illinois-judge-imposes-1m-sanction-over-frivolous-claims) against a man and his lawyer for filing what she called a “frivolous” lawsuit against his condominium association. The man, Marshall Spiegel, claimed that Brennan had held unethical conversations with the other party outside of the courtroom, and that the sanctions were retaliation for his effort to remove her from the case.

In 2012, Brennan reversed an administrative law judge’s decision that the [Chicago Bears owed Cook County](https://www.chicagotribune.com/business/chi-bears-delinquent-taxes-20140807-story.html) $4.1 million more in amusement taxes than they had paid. Brennan’s decision in that case was, itself, reversed in 2014.

In an emailed statement, Brennan disputed Injustice Watch's accounting of her reversals and said they represent "approximately 1%" of her decisions. She also denied retaliating against litigants or attorneys.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN SHERLOCK
general for COOK - 3RD SUBCIRCUIT - FILAN VACANCY
Suit seeking to erase fines for distracted driving moves forward
KERRY M. KENNEDY
fields.bio: Kerry M. Kennedy was elected to the Circuit Court in 2002. He currently hears cases in the fifth municipal district in Bridgeview. Before becoming a judge, he spent his entire 23-year career as a Cook County assistant public defender.
fields.notable:
During a 2006 rape trial, Kennedy threatened to jail the alleged victim for contempt of court if she wouldn’t watch a video of the sexual assault. He eventually backed off [after criticism from the Illinois Coalition Against Sexual Assault](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2006-03-02-0603020210-story.html).
In 2016, Kennedy increased the bond for a man accused of driving under the influence and battery to a police officer from $2,000, which his mother was prepared to pay, to $50,000. The bond was later reduced by the Illinois Appellate Court. Kennedy declined to comment.

fields.name: Cook County's most unconventional judge takes justice beyond the bench
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN KENWORTHY
GERARDO TRISTAN, JR.
fields.bio: Gerardo Tristan Jr. was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court 14th subcircuit seat in November 2018 and currently oversees traffic cases at the Daley Center. Prior to his appointment, he worked as an assistant state’s attorney for 15 years. Tristan had worked briefly upon graduating law school in private practice and for the Chicago Board of Education.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations noted Tristan’s extensive trial experience and knowledge of the law. The ISBA said attorneys “specifically noted his proficiency in the technological aspects of courtroom litigation.” The CCL said respondents “praised his fairness.”

fields.name: KRISTA D. BUTLER
fields.currentJob: Public service administrator, Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services
fields.bio: Krista Butler has been a licensed attorney since 1993 and  is currently employed by the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services. She previously worked as a public service administrator for the Illinois Guardianship and Advocacy Commission. Her legal focuses include guardianship and juvenile justice matters.
fields.ratingNotes: Butler was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: Restorative Justice Courts now in Avondale, Englewood
general for COOK CIRCUIT- O'BRIEN VACANCY
Man seeks to replace ‘hostile’ judge who upped bond 2400%
ERIN HAGGERTY ANTONIETTI
fields.bio: Erin Antonietti worked as an assistant state’s attorney for over two decades before her June 2019 appointment to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy. She currently hears traffic cases in the First Municipal Division. As state’s attorney, Antonietti prosecuted a wide range of cases, including violent felonies, domestic violence cases and traffic violations. Antonietti has also been an adjunct professor in the criminal justice program at Prairie State College.
fields.notable: Antonietti has loaned over $100,000 to her own campaign committee.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted that Antonietti is “well regarded by her fellow judges and by the lawyers who appear in her court.” The CCL highlighted her litigation experience and wrote that, since taking the bench, she has demonstrated “good legal ability, temperament, and the ability to manage high volume courtrooms.”

fields.name: Illinois Supreme Court strikes down eavesdropping law
How a white police attorney got a West Side judge seat
LYNN WEAVER BOYLE
fields.bio: Lynn Weaver Boyle was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in December 2018. Prior to her appointment, Weaver Boyle worked at the Chicago office of Grotefeld Hoffman LLP, where she represented clients in commercial litigation. She began her legal career in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where she worked for almost a decade as an assistant state’s attorney in the criminal division. She currently hears municipal civil cases and traffic matters at the Daley Center.
fields.notable: Boyle’s election committee has raised over $250,000, most of which comes from her family.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA referenced Weaver Boyle’s extensive trial experience both in private practice and as an assistant state’s attorney, including her two years in the gang unit. The CCL called her a “respected practitioner with a good temperament.”

13th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 13th subcircuit covers the northwest suburbs of Palatine, Schaumburg, Hoffman Estates, South Barrington, and Streamwood.

fields.name: ELIZABETH ANNE WALSH
fields.bio: Elizabeth Walsh has worked as a trial attorney in private practice throughout her career. She focuses on civil law and has defended individuals and businesses facing lawsuits in civil court.
fields.ratingNotes: Both the CBA and CCL cited Walsh’s trial experience and legal knowledge. The ISBA said, “Attorneys respect her for her legal knowledge, preparation, temperament, and professionalism.”

general for COOK - 8TH SUBCIRCUIT - FLEMING VACANCY
WATCHDOGS: Federal funds for clout school operator despite probe
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN BROSNAHAN
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN MARTIN
Lawyer for ex-Maryville priest calls sex-abuse allegations ‘ridiculous’
PAMELA ELIZABETH LOZA
fields.bio: Pamela Elizabeth Loza was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2008, and currently hears child custody and child support cases. She was the supervising judge of the paternity/child support enforcement department before it was merged into the domestic relations division in 2014. Before becoming a judge, Loza worked in private practice, primarily focused on criminal defense and domestic relations. Before that she worked in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office for four years. Before she was a lawyer, she was the assistant director of Casa Central, where she ran legal clinics and other programs for the Humboldt Park-based community organization.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN COLLINS-DOLE
Two Cook County judges, indicted Ald. Ed Burke partnered in investment club
JAMIE GUERRA DICKLER
fields.bio: Jamie Guerra Dickler has been an assistant state’s attorney for her entire 14-year legal career. She is currently a first chair in the felony trial division, prosecuting a variety of felony cases, including murder, narcotics, fraud and sexual assault. Previously, she has worked in the misdemeanor, felony review and grand jury units.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Dickler’s “extensive experience” and “excellent demeanor.” The CCL praised her community involvement and wrote, “All reports indicate that Ms. Dickler is an ethical prosecutor with good abilities.” The ISBA highlighted her “substantial criminal jury and bench trial experience, including handling complex cases.”

fields.name: Attorney for judge now wants his due
KRISTYNA COLLEEN RYAN
fields.bio: Kristyna Colleen Ryan was elected to the Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. She currently hears cases in the fourth municipal district in Maywood. Since 2010, she has been assigned to the mental health treatment and veterans specialty courts, in addition to her regular rotation of traffic, misdemeanor, and bond court cases. This year she was assigned to run a new restorative justice court in Avondale. She has a certificate in environmental and energy law in addition to her J.D., and she began her career in the telecommunications industry, working on regulatory compliance for cell tower development. Before becoming a judge, she worked in private practice.
fields.notable:
When running for election in 2008, Ryan and three other candidates skipped the bar association evaluation process and formed a political action committee, “Citizens for an Independent Judiciary” and endorsed themselves, [according to the Chicago Tribune](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2008-10-05-0810040278-story.html). Ryan likely would have received an “unqualified” rating, because she had less than 10 years of legal experience at the time.

In an emailed statement, Ryan said "Citizens for an Independent Judiciary" was formed "solely for the purpose of reporting campaign related expenses" of the candidates and did not publicly endorse any candidates.

fields.name: Illinois Judge Imposes $1M Sanction Over ‘Frivolous’ Claims
MICHAEL A. FORTI
fields.bio:
Michael A. Forti was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2018 and served as a judge in the domestic relations division until late last year, when he was elected by the Circuit Court to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the 8th subcircuit seat open until the election; Forti is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

This is his second appointment to the bench by the Illinois Supreme Court, after he lost in the Democratic Party primary in 2018. He also ran unsuccessfully in 2012. Before his bids for office, Forti worked for 17 years in the City of Chicago Law Department and was chief counsel for the Illinois Department of Transportation.
fields.notable: While at the Chicago Law Department, Forti handled several high-profile cases, including one in which city attorneys—after nearly a decade—[reversed their position](https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/the-shocking-truth/Content?oid=892462) by no longer fighting defendant Andrew Wilson’s torture claims against notorious former Chicago Police Commander Jon Burge and others, while still arguing that some of the judgement in the case should not be paid by the city. Forti was also [lead counsel](http://primaries2012.elections.chicagotribune.com/editorial/michael-a-forti/index.html) for a case brought against the city of Chicago over its handgun ownership ban. The U.S. Supreme Court later [struck down the ban](https://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/06/28/us.scotus.handgun.ban/index.html). Forti is openly gay and an advocate for LGBTQ rights.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Forti’s varied legal experience and “fine demeanor.” The CCL wrote, “As a judge, he continues to receive very positive marks,” including for his handling of self-represented litigants in a manner that is “respectful and informative without going beyond the role of judge.”

fields.name: MAIRE AILEEN DEMPSEY
fields.currentJob: Partner at Hughes Socol Piers Resnick & Dym
fields.bio: Maire Aileen Dempsey has been a licensed attorney since 2002 and has worked at various law firms throughout her career. For the past 14 years, Dempsey has practiced medical malpractice defense. She is currently a partner at Hughes Socol Piers Resnick & Dym, Ltd. in Chicago.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations noted Demsey’s experience handling complex litigation. The CBA said she is “well regarded for her integrity, diligence, knowledge of the law, and excellent demeanor.” The ISBA said she is “known to be prepared and professional” and the CCL praised her temperament and legal ability.

fields.name: Appointed judge
fields.description: Appointed judges are those who have been appointed by the state Supreme Court to temporarily fill a vacancy. Having experience as a judge is a positive qualification, and the vetting that accompanies the nomination process may screen out unqualified candidates. However, according to Professor Tonja Jacobi of Northwestern University's Pritzker School of Law, "In Chicago, it probably is an indication that you've rubbed a lot of shoulders with a lot of political types."

fields.name: Judge 'Happily' Denies Bail For Accused Repeat DUI Offender
NICHOLE C. PATTON
fields.bio: Nichole Patton was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in June 2018 and currently oversees cases in the county division at the Daley Center. She had two separate stints in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, most recently in the mental health unit, where she sought civil commitment orders for individuals at mental health hospitals in Cook County. She also spent several years in private practice doing both civil and criminal defense, as well as transactional law and medical malpractice defense. This is her fourth run for the bench after losing elections in 2010 and 2012 and pulling out of a 2014 Appellate Court primary race.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Patton for her “extensive knowledge and experience in mental health law,” her temperament, and her treatment of unrepresented parties in her court. The ISBA said she is “well-prepared and is fair with a good temperament.” CCL reported that she is “a zealous advocate who is trustworthy and respectful both to clients and opposing counsel.”

fields.name: general for COOK - 9TH SUBCIRCUIT - LUCKMAN VACANCY
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN COOPER
Illinois courts clash: Does limiting juvenile offenders' social media use step on free speech?
12th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 12th subcircuit includes the northern suburbs of Winnetka, Glencoe, Northbrook and Wheeling and the northwest suburbs of Des Plaines, Mt. Prospect and Arlington Heights.

fields.name: DONNA L. COOPER
fields.bio: Donna L. Cooper was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. She currently serves in the juvenile justice division at the Markham Courthouse. Before becoming a judge, Cooper worked as an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago, an attorney for the Chicago Parks Department, and an assistant public defender. Cooper is also a retired colonel in the Illinois Army National Guard, where she served in the Judge Advocate General’s (JAG) Corps. In addition to her regular juvenile courtroom, Cooper also presides over the Englewood Restorative Justice Community Court, the second such court in Cook County, which offers a non-punitive alternative to prosecution to young people charged with certain non-violent offenses.
fields.notable: In 1993, Cooper became the first African American JAG in the Illinois Army National Guard, according to [an interview she did with the judicial blog “For What It’s Worth,”](https://leyhane.blogspot.com/2008/01/donna-l-cooper-in-her-own-words.html) and in 2003, she deployed to Iraq. From 2012 to 2013, she was the State Judge Advocate for the Illinois Army National Guard. In 2013, she was awarded a Military Medal of Merit and a Meritorious Service Medal before she retired after 25 years of military service.

fields.name: 14th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 14th subcircuit covers much of the Southwest Side of Chicago, including Bridgeport, Back of the Yards, Little Village, Brighton Park, and Gage Park, and the suburb of Cicero. It is home to the Leighton Criminal Court House and the Cook County Jail at 26th and California.

retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN WALKER
Former state's attorney
fields.description: History as a state's attorney is an important qualification in terms of experience, but there is [some evidence](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1745-9125.1988.tb00858.x) that former prosecutors may be less sympathetic to those who bring civil rights allegations and economic "underdogs" (consumers, tenants, etc.) and tend to side with the government — particularly in the case of criminal defendants.

fields.name: Obama taps Cook County Judge Patricia Martin to Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities
Break rules, be promoted
fields.description: As a prosecutor, Wadas was rebuked by the Appellate Court, which called his trial behavior “an insult to the court and to the dignity of the trial bar." Twice, appeals courts suggested that disciplinary action might be necessary.

fields.name: LEWIS NIXON
fields.bio: Lewis Nixon was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2001 before winning election to the bench in 2002. He is the supervising judge of the mortgage foreclosure section of the chancery division. Nixon started his legal career as an assistant U.S. attorney in the Northern District of Illinois in 1975. He moved to the private sector for several years, first as an associate at a law firm and then as an attorney for Burlington Northern Railroad. Before becoming a judge, he spent 15 years as regional counsel for the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. He is a past president of the Illinois Judges Association.
fields.notable: In 2011, Nixon was appointed chairman of an Illinois Supreme Court special committee on foreclosures. Following the committee’s recommendations, the court in 2013 set new rules that required lenders to prove to judges that they had exhausted all efforts to help a borrower before foreclosing on a home.

fields.name: MAUREEN WARD KIRBY
fields.bio: Maureen Ward Kirby was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2007 and elected in 2008. She hears election, tax, civil mental health, and adoption cases in the county division. Before becoming a judge, she practiced commercial litigation as a partner at a Chicago law firm. She serves on an Illinois Supreme Court advisory committee on justice and mental health planning.

fields.name: 8th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 8th subcircuit extends north along the lakefront from Chinatown to Edgewater, and includes the South Loop, the Loop, Near North Side, Lincoln Park, Lakeview and Uptown.

fields.name: Bears owe Cook County $4 million in delinquent taxes
JUDITH RICE
fields.bio: Judith Rice was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014. She currently hears cases in the domestic relations division. Before becoming a judge, Rice worked for BMO Harris Bank from 2007 to 2014, including stints as director of government relations and senior vice president of community affairs and economic development. Before that, Rice had a long career in the public sector. She worked briefly as an assistant state’s attorney in the late 1980s before working for the City of Chicago, first in the law department, and then as a managing deputy director in the Department of Revenue. Rice served as the first female commissioner of both the Chicago Department of Water (1996 to 1999) and the Chicago Department of Transportation (1999 to 2000). She also served as the city treasurer from 2000 and 2006, and as deputy chief of staff to Mayor Richard M. Daley from 2006 to 2007. Rice has served on the boards of March of Dimes, UCAN, the Chicago Public Library, Neighborhood Housing Services, the Civic Federation, and the Illinois State Board of Elections.
fields.notable: Rice’s father, Fred Rice, was Chicago’s first Black police commissioner.

fields.name: Judge blocks key legal protection for detained youth
general for COOK CIRCUIT- SHEEHAN, C. VACANCY
MARY CATHERINE MARUBIO
fields.bio: Mary Catherine Marubio has been an associate judge in the Cook County Circuit Court since 2016. She is currently assigned to the pretrial division and was previously assigned to the domestic relations division. Prior to her election to the bench, she worked at the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation as an administrative law judge and as the chief of the prosecutions bureau. Marubio has also worked in criminal defense as a private attorney.
fields.notable: Marubio is active in the LGBTQ community and in 2019 received the Community Leadership Award from the Illinois State Bar Association’s Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Committee. She has also served on the board of the ACLU of Illinois.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA reported that Marubio “has a keen intellect, is a hard worker and has a good temperament” and the CBA said she is “dedicated to her assignments.” The CCL said that, as a lawyer, Marubio was a “smart, solid practitioner with a variety of litigation experiences.”

fields.name: ROBERT E. GORDON
fields.bio: Robert E. Gordon has served on the Illinois Appellate Court by appointment since 2006, and is currently the presiding judge of the fourth division of the first district. He was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1996 and was first elected in 2002. Before becoming a judge, Gordon was an attorney in private practice, primarily in the areas of insurance defense litigation and general litigation. He also spent time in public office as a Village Trustee of Northbrook from 1975 to 1984. Gordon has sat on numerous boards and committees, including the Appellate Court Administrative Committee, which evaluates possible methods for improving the appeals process.
fields.notable: Gordon has issued several rulings in favor of alleged police torture survivors. Last year, he joined two other appellate judges in [overturning the conviction](https://courts.illinois.gov/Opinions/AppellateCourt/2018/1stDistrict/1162177.pdf) of James Gibson, harshly criticizing the associate judge who ruled that Gibson’s claims of torture were not credible. In 2017, [he wrote an opinion](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/decades-after-alleged-torture-by-police-years-more-wait-to-have-cases-resolved/) granting Sean Tyler an evidentiary hearing on his claims of being coerced into a confession by detectives who had worked under disgraced former police Cmdr. Jon Burge.

fields.name: GARY WILLIAM SEYRING
fields.bio: Gary Seyring has worked throughout his decades-long career in private practice on a wide range of civil matters, including business and family law. He has also done arbitration for the Cook County Arbitration Program. Seyring is running in the 13th subcircuit for the fourth time, after losing in the primaries in 2014 and 2016 and, after winning the Republican primary in 2018, losing in the general election.
fields.notable: In 2018, Seyring’s campaign Facebook page identified him as “the only true conservative Republican in the race for judge.”
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL said a “substantial percentage” of Seyring’s practice involves litigation and the ISBA said he is considered “a well-prepared litigator.” The CBA said Seyring is “actively involved in community service and highly regarded by the judges before whom he has appeared.”

fields.name: CASANDRA LEWIS
fields.bio: Casandra Lewis was first elected to the bench in 2002. Before becoming a judge, she spent two years as an assistant state’s attorney in Kane County and nine years in private practice, focusing on criminal and family law.
fields.notable: Lewis reported that she or an immediate family member received a monetary gift of $12,250 from the Church of God in Christ, where she currently serves as an associate justice on the church’s Judiciary Board. Lewis declined to comment.

fields.name: Controversial decision to grant bail to young man accused of shooting a cop
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN PORTMAN-BROWN
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN KYRIAKOPOULOS
JOHN CURRY
fields.bio: John Curry was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2014, after winning the Republican primary and running unopposed for a seat in the 13th subcircuit. He currently hears cases in the law division. Before becoming a judge, he was a partner in the Chicago office of Polsinelli PC, a national law firm, focusing on commercial litigation. Before that he worked as an Illinois assistant attorney general and later as an attorney in the Civil Rights division of the U.S. Department of Justice in the Reagan administration. He was a longtime elected member of the Cook County Republican Central Committee, and has worked on Republican campaigns including Ronald Reagan, Jim Thompson, Jim Edgar, and others. He is a founder of the Chicago Lawyers Division of the Federalist Society for Law and Public Policy, a conservative legal group.

fields.name: After 31 years in prison, Chicago man awarded $5.2 million in case city bitterly fought
Judge Tosses Suit Challenging DCFS Ban on Supervised In-Person Visits During Pandemic
Defeated judges find way back to the bench
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN TOOMIN
JOAN E. POWELL
fields.bio: Joan E. Powell was elected to the Circuit Court of Cook County in 2008, and retained in 2014. She currently serves in the law division hearing jury trials. Before becoming a judge, she was a law clerk for former Circuit Court Judge Joseph Casciato from 1996 to 2000, and later became an assistant state's attorney in the civil division. Before that, she was an attorney in private practice in family and contract law for four years.

fields.name: JAMES N. O'HARA
fields.bio: James O’Hara was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2008 and won election later that year. He currently hears personal injury and medical malpractice cases in the law division. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private practice and also for a time at Merrill Lynch. He also had stints in the Cook County Public Defender’s Office and in the Illinois Attorney General’s Office.

fields.name: GREGORY J. WOJKOWSKI
fields.bio: Gregory J. Wojkowski was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1996, and is currently assigned to the law division. He previously heard civil jury trials in the first municipal division. Before becoming a judge, he spent 16 years in the City of Chicago’s Law Department, where he held several positions, culminating with chief assistant corporation counsel in the litigation division. He represented the city in several police misconduct lawsuits.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN SULLIVAN
Lombard couple accused of defrauding donors now barred from fundraising
LORRAINE MARY MURPHY
fields.bio: Lorraine Murphy has spent much of her career at the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where she has prosecuted a variety of different types of cases in the felony trial division. Prior to her legal career, she worked in broadcast journalism. This is Murphy’s second run for the bench after an unsuccessful bid for a 10th subcircuit seat in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL and CBA noted Murphy’s trial experience and courtroom skills. The ISBA wrote that she is respected as an “accomplished attorney with impressive legal knowledge.” Murphy is a CBA member and she served on their Judicial Evaluation Committee.

fields.name: retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN WATKINS
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN MAHONEY
Diversity at stake in competitive Illinois Supreme Court race
retention for COOK CIRCUIT - RETAIN LEWIS
DOMINIQUE C. ROSS
fields.bio: Dominique Ross was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2008 and retained in 2014. She has been assigned to the domestic relations division, hearing divorce and child support cases, since 2009. Before becoming a judge, she was an attorney in private practice for 13 years focused on domestic relations and family law. She is a past chair of the Illinois Judges Council, an association of Black judges.
fields.notable:
Ross was sued in 2009 by an election attorney she hired for allegedly failing to pay him more than $60,000 for his work. She filed a counter-claim, and the case was settled six months later. Ross has also served on the board of a Des Plaines-based charter school network, Concept Schools, which was investigated in 2014 for allegedly defrauding a federal grant program.

In an emailed statement, Ross said the federal grant program was "not presented to the board" during her time.
